section: i-on will maintain the operation of the Hosted Site continuously, twenty-four (24) hours per day, seven (7) days per week, including holidays, with the exception of reasonable hardware and software maintenance that must be performed on the Hosting Computer and/or the Hosted Site. i-on will use best efforts to schedule and perform such maintenance between the hours of 8pm and 8am Eastern Standard Time on weekdays, or during weekends.
explanation: The text states 24/7 availability 'with the exception of reasonable hardware and software maintenance'. While understandable, 'reasonable' is ambiguous. There is no defined limit to the duration or frequency of 'reasonable' maintenance. This ambiguity could lead to disputes if the customer believes the maintenance is excessive, while i-on considers it reasonable. The lack of clarity makes it difficult to objectively determine if i-on is fulfilling its obligation to 'maintain the operation of the Hosted Site continuously.'

section: connectivity to the Internet. Specific connectivity details are outlined in a separate service level agreement (SLA).
explanation: The contract mentions a separate SLA outlining connectivity details. If the SLA is not attached or explicitly incorporated by reference into this agreement, it creates ambiguity. The customer cannot be certain of the specific connectivity details they are entitled to. Furthermore, without the SLA being part of the contract, there is no guarantee that it is legally binding under the terms of this agreement.
location: SERVICES PROVIDED TO THE CUSTOMER, Point 1

section: use of the Microsoft Windows NT Server 4.0 or higher operating system software for the Hosting Computer and the Hosted Site;
explanation: The text provides using 'Microsoft Windows NT Server 4.0 or higher'. This statement creates an ambiguity because Windows NT Server 4.0 is a very old operating system. Specifying “or higher” is not sufficient because there can be incompatibility issues with newer software. This introduces ambiguity and opens the door to potential performance or security issues that could reasonably be expected to be addressed with modern server software.
location: SERVICES PROVIDED TO THE CUSTOMER, Point 8

section: The Customer is responsible for paying the recurring monthly fees by the 5th day of each month. The Customer acknowledges that failure to pay such fees in a timely manner will result in the interruption or discontinuation of services for the Hosted Site.
explanation: While stating that failure to pay fees results in interruption or discontinuation of services is clear, there is no clarification on the process or timeline for such actions. Is the service immediately interrupted on the 6th? Is there a grace period, notification, or opportunity to rectify the situation? The lack of detail creates ambiguity and could lead to disputes over the fairness and legality of service interruption.

section: The Customer is responsible for any and all software programs, server-side scripts, and/or executable components that are installed on the Hosting Computer for the purpose of providing interactive applications or dynamic content on the Hosted Site. Any such programs, scripts, or components that might affect the stability of the Hosting Computer or interfere with other Web sites on the Hosting Computer must be approved by i-on before being installed on the Hosted Site, i-on reserves the right to deny the Customer permission to install any such programs, scripts, or components, to require additional fees for the installation and/or ongoing operation of any such programs, scripts, or components, or to remove any such programs, scripts, or components, if in i-on's sole discretion they will interfere with the operation of the Hosting Computer or exceed the Customer's monthly allocation of Web administration services.
explanation: i-on reserves the right to deny permission, require additional fees, or remove programs at its 'sole discretion' if they interfere with the Hosting Computer or exceed the Customer's monthly allocation of web administration services. The subjectivity of 'sole discretion' without any defined standards or appeal process is problematic. It gives i-on considerable power with little accountability. This creates ambiguity about the conditions under which software will be allowed and can lead to disputes.

section: This Agreement shall automatically be renewed for one (1) or more one (1) month periods unless either the Customer or i-on gives notice to the other party of its intention not to renew the Agreement, which notice must be given not less than fifteen (15) days before the end of the respective initial or renewal term. Either party may terminate this Agreement without cause at any time effective upon thirty (30) days' written notice.
explanation: This section allows for automatic renewal for 'one (1) or more one (1) month periods'. This language is contradictory, since it is not clear on how many months it will auto-renew for. Will it renew for one month and then stop, or renew for an infinite amount of months?

section: i-on will not be liable under any circumstances for any lost profits or other consequential damages, even if i-on has been advised as to the possibility of such damages. i-on's liability for damages to the Customer for any cause whatsoever, regardless of the form of action, and whether in contract or in tort, including negligence, shall be limited to one (1) month's fees and the remaining portion of any prepaid fees.
explanation: The clause states that i-on's liability is limited to 'one (1) month's fees and the remaining portion of any prepaid fees.' This limitation may be unenforceable depending on the jurisdiction and the nature of the damages. A complete exclusion of liability for gross negligence or willful misconduct is often against public policy and may be legally challenged. This section's enforceability is therefore questionable.

section: The Customer agrees to indemnify and hold harmless i-on, against any lawsuits, claims, damages, or liabilities (or actions or proceedings in respect thereof) to which i-on may become subject related to or arising out of Customer's use of i-on's services, and will reimburse i-on for all legal and other expenses, including attorney's fees, incurred in connection with investigating, defending, or settling any such loss, claim, damage, liability, action, or proceeding whether or not in connection with pending or threatened litigation in which i-on is a party.
explanation: The indemnification clause is very broad, requiring the Customer to indemnify i-on against liabilities 'related to or arising out of Customer's use of i-on's services'. This lacks specificity. If i-on is negligent and that negligence contributes to a claim, the Customer could still be liable to indemnify i-on under this language. Many jurisdictions limit indemnification to situations where the customer's actions are the primary cause of the liability.
